comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: This is NOT a Red Cross ambulance. From 1915 onwards the members of the Irish Automobile club modified their personal cars into ambulances at their own expense and ferried wounded Irish solders returning from the European hostilities to hospitals and convalescent homes around the country. When the Rising occurred they continued to carry the wounded from both sides to medical attention. At least one driver was shot in the process, happily without fatal consequences.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Thanks a lot, Bob, for another great contribution! I've added it to the description under the photo above...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 83987525@N04
comment._content:
The Irish Association of Volunteer Training Corps(VTC) disbanded in late 1916. The VTC were also known as the Gorgeous Wrecks from their Georgius Rex armbands.

From the disbanded Kingstown and District VTC sprang the Soldiers' and Sailors' Guides Corps in January 1917, a group which aimed to meet and greet soldiers and sailors returning to Ireland and ensure they got where they needed to, especially those who were wounded. 

The VTC had been doing some of this work prior to their disbandment.

The 1916 Rebellion Handbook has a good amount of information re the work of the St John Ambulance, Voluntary Aid Detachments and the hospitals during the Easter Rising and is well worth a read.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/59021143@N05] Thanks for that! Now added to our tags.
